Title: Colonization, Early Institutions and the Origin of State Capacity and Democratization

This project seeks to investigate the origins of state capacity and democratization by examining the colonial conquest of Latin America. Focusing on the initial years of Spanish colonization, when conquerors lacked knowledge of the land, we will analyze the role of early institutions in shaping the trajectory of state development and democratic outcomes. Our research will leverage a unique combination of case studies, panel data, and country-fixed effects, as well as instrumental variables, to identify the causal relationships between colonial-era institutions and long-term political outcomes.

Utilizing the rich archival resources of the Capitulaciones and Archivo de Indias, we will gather detailed information on the rules governing early institutions and the location of initial settlements at the subnational level. This approach allows us to isolate the effects of institutional design on state capacity and democratization, while controlling for other potential confounding factors. Our findings will contribute to a deeper understanding of the historical roots of political development and inform strategies for promoting democratic governance and institutional reform in developing countries. By shedding new light on the origins of state capacity and democratization, this project has the potential to make a significant impact on our understanding of political development and its implications for economic growth, stability, and human well-being.

Title: Colonization, Early Institutions and the Origin of State Capacity and Democratization

This project seeks to illuminate the historical roots of state capacity and democratization by examining the colonial conquest of Latin America. Focusing on the initial years of Spanish colonization, we capitalize on the conquerors' limited knowledge of the land to analyze the formation of early institutions and their long-term impact on state capacity and democratization. Our research leverages a unique combination of case studies, panel data, and country-fixed effects, supplemented by instrumental variables, to identify causal relationships between colonial institutions and modern political outcomes.

Our approach is facilitated by the rich documentation of the Spanish colonial period, including the Capitulaciones and Archivo de Indias, which provide detailed information on the rules governing early institutions and the location of initial settlements at the subnational level. By exploiting this historical context, we aim to contribute to a deeper understanding of how colonial legacies shape state capacity and democratization, and to shed new light on the role of political dynasties in this process. Ultimately, this project promises to provide valuable insights for policymakers and scholars seeking to promote more effective and democratic governance in Latin America and beyond.

Title: Colonization, Early Institutions, and the Origin of State Capacity and Democratization

This project seeks to uncover the historical roots of state capacity and democratization in Latin America, focusing on the critical period of colonial conquest. By examining the initial years of Spanish colonization, we can isolate the effects of institutional design on long-term political outcomes, unencumbered by the complexities of later historical events. Our research leverages the rich documentation of the Capitulaciones and Archivo de Indias, which provide detailed information on the rules governing early institutions and the location of initial settlements at the subnational level.

Through a mixed-methods approach combining case studies, panel data analysis, and country-fixed effects, we will investigate how the early institutional arrangements established by Spanish colonizers influenced the development of state capacity and democratic institutions. Instrumental variables will be employed to address potential endogeneity issues. This project's unique contribution lies in its focus on the foundational period of colonization, when the conquerors lacked knowledge about the land, allowing for a more controlled examination of institutional design and its consequences.

By shedding light on the historical origins of state capacity and democratization in Latin America, this research aims to inform contemporary debates on institutional development, democratic consolidation, and the persistence of political dynasties. Ultimately, this project seeks to provide a deeper understanding of the complex interplay between colonial legacy, institutional design, and long-term political outcomes.
